question.title: How to free memory using Java Unsafe, using a Java reference?

node.contents: The question probably arises from an idea that `Unsafe.allocateInstance` might allocate objects out of Java Heap. But this is not true. `allocateInstance` works exactly like `new Object()` except that it does not call constructor.

astNode.text: The question probably arises from an idea that `Unsafe.allocateInstance` might allocate objects out of Java Heap. But this is not true. `allocateInstance` works exactly like `new Object()` except that it does not call constructor.

node.contents: To free memory "held" by a Java reference you null the reference.

astNode.text: To free memory "held" by a Java reference you null the reference.

node.contents: Theoretically, yes, because Unsafe allows you to do anything the JVM can do (by manipulating the JVM's memory). Doing so would require intricate knowledge of the internal implementation details of the JVM. (In other words: no, you can't.)

astNode.text: Theoretically, yes, because Unsafe allows you to do anything the JVM can do (by manipulating the JVM's memory). Doing so would require intricate knowledge of the internal implementation details of the JVM. (In other words: no, you can't.)

node.contents: Java Unsafe class allows you to allocate memory for an object as follows, but using this method how would you free up the memory allocated when finished, as it does not provide the memory address...

astNode.text: Java Unsafe class allows you to allocate memory for an object as follows, but using this method how would you free up the memory allocated when finished, as it does not provide the memory address...

elements.contents: Field f = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); //Internal reference f.setAccessible(true); Unsafe unsafe = (Unsafe) f.get(null); //This creates an instance of player class without any initialization Player p = (Player) unsafe.allocateInstance(Player.class);

comments.text: //Internal reference f.setAccessible(true); Unsafe unsafe = (Unsafe) f.get(null); //This creates an instance of player class without any initialization Player p = (Player) unsafe.allocateInstance(Player.class);

units.rawText: Field f = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); //Internal reference f.setAccessible(true); Unsafe unsafe = (Unsafe) f.get(null); //This creates an instance of player class without any initialization Player p = (Player) unsafe.allocateInstance(Player.class);

node.contents: Is there a way of accessing the memory address from the object reference, maybe the integer returned by the default hashCode implementation will work, so you could do...

astNode.text: Is there a way of accessing the memory address from the object reference, maybe the integer returned by the default hashCode implementation will work, so you could do...

node.contents:
• "Memory address" of an object reference does not make sense since objects can move across Java Heap.
  • You cannot explicitly free space allocated by Unsafe.allocateInstance, because this space belongs to Java Heap, and only Garbage Collector can free it.
  • If you want your own memory management outside Java Heap, you may use Unsafe.allocateMemory / Unsafe.freeMemory methods. They deal with raw memory addresses represented as long. However this memory is not for Java objects.

astNode.text:
• "Memory address" of an object reference does not make sense since objects can move across Java Heap.
  • You cannot explicitly free space allocated by Unsafe.allocateInstance, because this space belongs to Java Heap, and only Garbage Collector can free it.
  • If you want your own memory management outside Java Heap, you may use Unsafe.allocateMemory / Unsafe.freeMemory methods. They deal with raw memory addresses represented as long. However this memory is not for Java objects.

node.contents: 1) `Unsafe.freeMemory` works only on malloc'ed addresses. Java objects are never malloc'ed. Allocation in Java Heap is completely different. 2) Your `addressOf` does not return an address at all whenever `CompressedOops` is on.

astNode.text: 1) `Unsafe.freeMemory` works only on malloc'ed addresses. Java objects are never malloc'ed. Allocation in Java Heap is completely different. 2) Your `addressOf` does not return an address at all whenever `CompressedOops` is on.

node.contents: You can read out the object's fields from the returned address and there are libraries built around this. But you are right, one should additionally check for compressed pointers. Anyways, the example demonstrates that even with a pointer, you could not free the memory as you can read in my answer.

astNode.text: You can read out the object's fields from the returned address and there are libraries built around this. But you are right, one should additionally check for compressed pointers. Anyways, the example demonstrates that even with a pointer, you could not free the memory as you can read in my answer.

node.contents: Is it possible to do this efficiently for Java Objects in off-heap memory?

astNode.text: Is it possible to do this efficiently for Java Objects in off-heap memory?

node.contents: No. It is not possible at all as I stated in the answer. I posted the example code to show that even the attempt to trick the memory management will not turn out as expected. You are not able to avoid the racing condition (you cannot trigger a *stop the world* event such as the garbage collector can) so even on a VM that supports this kind of use, you could not apply this "solution".

astNode.text: No. It is not possible at all as I stated in the answer. I posted the example code to show that even the attempt to trick the memory management will not turn out as expected. You are not able to avoid the racing condition (you cannot trigger a *stop the world* event such as the garbage collector can) so even on a VM that supports this kind of use, you could not apply this "solution".

node.contents: You can theoretically free memory of any address using Unsafe::freeMemory after reading an instance's memory address:

astNode.text: You can theoretically free memory of any address using Unsafe::freeMemory after reading an instance's memory address:

elements.contents: Object o = new Object(); long objectAddress = addressOf(o, unsafe); unsafe.freeMemory(objectAdress);

units.rawText: Object o = new Object(); long objectAddress = addressOf(o, unsafe); unsafefreeMemory(objectAdress);

elements.contents: long addressOf(Object o, Unsafe unsafe) throws Exception { Object[] array = new Object[]{o}; long baseOffset = unsafe.arrayBaseOffset(Object[].class); switch (unsafe.addressSize()) { case 4: return unsafe.getInt(array, baseOffset); case 8: return unsafe.getLong(array, baseOffset); default: throw new AssertionError(); } }

units.rawText: long addressOf(Object o, Unsafe unsafe) throws Exception { Object[] array = new Object[]{o}; long baseOffset = unsafe.arrayBaseOffset(Object[].class); switch (unsafe.addressSize()) { case 4: return unsafe.getInt(array, baseOffset); case 8: return unsafe.getLong(array, baseOffset); default: throw new AssertionError(); } }

node.contents: However, you will notice that your application will freeze on a HotSpot VM. The behavior of freeing an object this way is not specified as the Java heap can be reorganized so you are at least facing a heavy racing condition, even if it worked. The Unsafe::freeMemory method must therefore only be used on memory that was allocated with Unsafe::allocateMemory. Java is not C++, do not get involved in the memory management. If you really need this, you did something else wrong.

astNode.text: However, you will notice that your application will freeze on a HotSpot VM. The behavior of freeing an object this way is not specified as the Java heap can be reorganized so you are at least facing a heavy racing condition, even if it worked. The Unsafe::freeMemory method must therefore only be used on memory that was allocated with Unsafe::allocateMemory. Java is not C++, do not get involved in the memory management. If you really need this, you did something else wrong.
